node.title: What is the risk of COVID spread from an unvaccinated family member or friend?
node.description: As people gather to celebrate the festive season, health experts say there are measures everyone can take to limit the risk of COVID.Â
node.content:
["It might feel a little like deja vu.\u00a0Australia is heading into a second festive summer season with COVID front of mind,\u00a0and, in parts, in the community.", "While the risks of the virus persist, there's been exponential progress in the last 12 months, with most of the country now partially or fully vaccinated.\u00a0", "As family and friends look to gather over the holiday season, and cases of community transmission continue\u00a0to spread in Victoria, New South Wales, the Northern Territory and more recently South Australia,\u00a0there are calls for people to take appropriate precautions.\u00a0", "
How many Australians are vaccinated against COVID?\u00a0
", "Despite a late start, Australia is now among the most vaccinated countries in the world.\u00a0", "As of December 2, more than 87 per cent of the population over the age of 16 had\u00a0been fully vaccinated.\u00a0", "Vaccines have been shown to help reduce the risk of infection, as well as the severity of disease if infected.", "However, experts \u2014\u00a0including professor of epidemiology at UNSW Mary-Louise McLaws \u2014\u00a0advise that they are not a silver bullet against the virus.", "\"Vaccinated people with Pfizer are covered against death, hospitalisation, and severe illness but they are not completely covered for acquiring symptomatic or asymptomatic infection,\" Professor McLaws said.\u00a0", "The risks of COVID are highest for those who aren't yet vaccinated.", "They are more likely to be hospitalised, end up in the intensive care unit, or, in a worst-case scenario, die.", "", "
Mary-Louise McLaws is a\u00a0member of the WHO's Health Emergencies Program Experts Advisory Panel for Infection Prevention and Control Preparedness.(ABC News: Brendan Esposito)
", "
I'm vaccinated. What is the risk to me from an unvaccinated person?\u00a0
", "We know from multiple studies that indoors and homes are high-risk settings.", "Earlier this year, researchers at the University of Melbourne looked at the relative risk of spreading COVID\u00a0between those who have and have not been vaccinated in social settings.\u00a0", "It showed that not only are unvaccinated people more likely to get COVID, they're also more likely to spread it \u2014\u00a020 times more likely, in fact.", "The study points out that while there are various factors that affect the exact risk level, such as the type of vaccine or the time since vaccination, the general rule is clear: the higher the levels of vaccination in a group, the lower the chances of spread.\u00a0", "In addition, a relatively small study\u00a0in the United Kingdom\u00a0found\u00a0that while vaccination\u00a0didn't affect the maximum amount of virus\u00a0you carry if infected, it did reduce\u00a0the amount of time COVID-positive people are infectious.", "Professor of biostatistics\u00a0Adrian Esterman explains it like this: \"If you are fully vaccinated you actually have that viral load for a much shorter period of time because your immune system can kill off the virus much quicker.\"", "\"With Delta, someone who is not vaccinated is on average infectious for 7.5 days. This compares with 5.5 days for someone who is fully vaccinated.\"\u00a0", "", "
Adrian Esterman is an epidemiologist at the University of South Australia.(ABC News)
", "
Should I invite an unvaccinated family member or friend to a gathering?
", "Professor Esterman says he would not take the risk.\u00a0", "\"I would say, look, we've been friends for 20 years, but unless you have been vaccinated I am not willing to have you in my home.\"", "For children who are under 12 years of age and are unable to get vaccinated, Professor Esterman says families should weigh up the risk as to whether they should get a test before seeing vulnerable people.\u00a0", "Epidemiologist Mary-Louise McLaws says asking guests to get tested ahead of the event is an alternative.\u00a0", "\"Getting vaccinated is not just about yourself, it's about what we do for the wider community.\"\u00a0", "Watch the full discussion on The Drum, available on ABC iview.", "", "
Heavily mutated Omicron variant puts scientist on alert
